title: Centre May Fix Gold Holding Limit, Manipur Separatists Announce Exiled Govt + More Top News
text:
Two Manipuri men who claim to represent the titular King Leishemba Sanajaoba have announced the setting up of what they called the "Manipur Government in exile" in the UK.

The two men, Yamben Biren, claiming to be the "Chief Minister of Manipur State Council" and Narengbam Samarjit, claiming to be the "Minister of External Affairs and Defence of Manipur State Council" made the announcement in London.

The duo claimed that they were speaking on behalf of the Maharaja of Manipur to formally launch the government-in-exile. Read More

Government Likely To Fix Holding Limit, Announce 'Amnesty' Scheme For Unaccounted Gold

In an attempt to crack down on black money and unaccounted gold, the government is planning to set a holding limit for the yellow metal.

The PMO and the Finance Ministry are giving finishing touches to a scheme aimed at legalizing unaccounted wealth in gold, CNBC reported.

According to the report, individuals be allowed to disclose unaccounted gold (gold without receipt) beyond a certain threshold and pay taxes on the disclosed value. Read More

After Nepal, Pakistan Releases New Coin To Commemorate 550th Anniversary Of Guru Nanak Dev

The government of Pakistan has released a new coin in order to commemorate the 550th anniversary of Baba Guru Nanak. The coin worth Pakistan Rupees 50 will be available at the Kartarpur Sahib along with a postal stamp worth PKR 8 to the travelling pilgrims, news agency ANI reported, quoting Dunya News.

Meanwhile, India on Tuesday shared a list of 575 pilgrims scheduled to attend the inaugural 'jatha' to Gurudwara Kartarpur Sahib through the Kartarpur corridor in Pakistan. Read More

Mumbai At Risk Of Being Wiped Out By Rising Seas By 2050

Pro-environment groups and activists have long been warning people of the dangers of the rising sea level but neither have we committed ourselves to preventing the melting of glaciers and global warming, which are leading to rising sea levels, nor do the forces of nature seem to work on our sides. Alarming projections are coming to the fore repeatedly these days.

In a new research, it has been found that rising seas could affect three times more people by 2050 than previously thought, and what’s more worrying, India's financial capital, Mumbai, is at the risk of being 'wiped out'.

The New York Times has reported that the "authors of a paper published last week developed a more accurate way of calculating land elevation based on satellite readings, a standard way of estimating the effects of sea-level rise over large areas, and found that the previous numbers were far too optimistic." Read More

Depressed IIT-Hyderabad Student Leaps To Death From Hostel Building

Making it to one of the IITs, graduating from there and getting placed in a top global tech company is still one of the biggest dreams of millions of aspiring Indians.

It is like a rat race for young minds, which is often fueled by peer and family pressure to succeed.

But not everyone who dreams about it can make it successfully. And this can have serious consequences including driving them to depression and even suicide. Read More
